awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies religious fundamentalism, focusing on contrasting groups in a single political entity. The adherents of fundamentalist movements consider their religion to be a system of absolute truth, promote strict conformity to the religious laws and moral precepts specified in the scriptures, and have mustered considerable influence in some regions in recent decades. It is, however, unclear to what extent the groups studied here hold fundamentalist beliefs and attitudes. To make this assessment, this project will launch a full-scale survey of religious fundamentalism and other cultural and sociopolitical values. Building on a earlier study of the subject in the region, this project evaluates the similarities and differences in fundamentalism between people in different groups throughout the region.  This project also gauges how fundamentalist beliefs and attitudes among individuals are linked to their (a) religiosity, (b) identity, (c) liberal values, (d) the feelings of insecurity and xenophobia, (e) sources of information, and (f) demographics.  Increased understanding of what affects societal values and weakens fundamentalism contributes to a better knowledge of how to engineer peace and avoid conflict.

The existence of considerable variability in the fundamentalist movements among the followers of the Abrahamic faiths complicates comparative analysis of the subject, hampers empirical generalization across these faiths, and poses difficulties in theoretical abstraction. To overcome these challenges, this project theorizes that fundamentalists, despite their variabilities across religions and sects, share core orientations toward their own and other religions. These core orientations rest on a disciplinarian conception of the deity, literalism or inerrancy, religious exclusivity, and religious intolerance. To measure these orientations, a fundamentalism scale based on a battery of sixteen survey questions was constructed and validated. This study employs this scale to gauge fundamentalism among a representative sample of 3,300 adult respondents from contrasting groups, using both face-to-face and online interviews. By developing a fundamentalism scale that measures the subject in all the Abrahamic faiths, this project makes a significant contribution to the social-scientific study of fundamentalism and comparative religious studies. The collected dataset will also serve as an infrastructure for comparative analysis and make it possible to engage in scientific dialogue among different researchers studying the subject in the region and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Measuring and Assessing Religious Fundamentalism among Israeli Jews and Israeli Muslim Arabs

Mansoor Moaddel

moaddel@umd.edu

 Objectives

This research project was a collaboration between Mansoor Moaddel, Professor of Sociology at the University of Maryland-College Park, and Julia Elad-Strenger, Assistant Professor of Political Psychology at Bar-Ilan University in Israel. Professors Samer Halaby at Academic College of Tel Aviv Yaffo, and Shlomo Fischer at Hebrew University and the Jewish People Policy Institute joined this project as research consultants. Building on a cross-national survey of fundamentalism among Middle Eastern Muslims and Christians, this project assessed (1) Moaddel-Karabenick fundamentalism scale among Jews in Israel, (2) the effect of the democratic context on fundamentalism among Israeli Jews and Israeli Muslim Arabs, (3) the predictors of fundamentalism among the followers of the Abrahamic faiths, and, finally, (4) the implications of the findings for peace and security.

Outcomes

The project carried out a national survey in Israel in December 2023.  It interviewed a probability sample of 2,145 Israeli Jews online, 300 members of the Haredim face-to-face, and 1,005 Israeli Muslim Arabs face-to-face. The survey was conducted by Geocartography Knowledge Group (GCKG), Tel Aviv, Israel. The questionnaire used in this study consisted of about 250 items that probed the respondents’ attitudes and values in different domains of social life, including religion, culture, politics, family, intergroup relations, and demographics. The following are some of the findings that are related to the October 7, 2023, terrorist attack.

ATTITUDE TOWARD THE WAR WITH HAMAS & PERCEPTION OF OCTOBER 7TH TERRORIST ATTACK

Fully 90% either strongly agreed or agreed that “Israel should destroy Hamas even if it causes mass Palestinian casualties,” while 5% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 5% DK/NR. Among Israeli Muslim Arabs, these percentages were 17%, 73%, and 10%, respectively.

 75% strongly agreed or agreed that “The terrorist attack on October 7 was the second holocaust,” 21% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 4% DK/NR.  Among Israeli Muslim Arabs, these percentages were 35%, 44%, and 21%, respectively.

 68% strongly agreed or agreed that “Israel should occupy all of the Gaza strip,” 21% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 11% DK/NR. These figures for Israeli Muslim Arabs were 11%, 82%, and 7%, respectively.

 On the question of “The current security crisis is a threat to the existence of the state of Israel,” there is almost a consensus between Jews and Muslim Arabs. 61% of Israeli Jews strongly agreed or agreed, 36% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 3% DK/NR. Among Israeli Muslim Arabs, these percentage were 62%, 29%, and 9%, respectively.

 LITTLE SUPPORT FOR PEACE WITH PALESTINIANS OR A PALESTINIAN STATE

Only 13% strongly agreed or agreed that “Israel would be a better place, if there was a Palestinian state side by side with Israel,” 72% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 15% DK/NR. Among Israeli Muslim Arabs, these percentages were 80%, 14%, and 6%, respectively.

A small minority, 11%, strongly agreed or agreed that “Only peace with Palestinians can eradicate Hamas,” 77% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 12% DK/NR. Among Israeli Arabs, these percentages were 40%, 39%, and 21%, respectively.

Only a minority, 13% strongly agreed or agreed that “After the war, Gaza must be solely managed by the Palestinian Authority,” while 69% disagreed or strongly disagreed and 18% DK/NR. Among Israeli Arabs, these percentages were 45%, 39%, and 15%, respectively.

Finally, 19% strongly agreed or agreed that “Israeli government should try to dismantle the settlements,” 66% disagreed or strongly disagreed, and 15% DK/NR, compared to 80%, 14%, and 6% among Muslim Arabs, respectively.

ISRAEL VERSUS OTHER MIDDLE EASTERN COUNTRIES ON FUNDAMENTALISM AND LIBERAL VALUES

This study was part of a larger project on measuring and assessing fundamentalism and liberal values across the Middle East. It constructed scales of fundamentalism (an average of the measures of disciplinarian deity, literalism, religious exclusivity, and religious intolerance) and liberal values (an average of the measures of expressive individualism, gender equality, and secular politics). Based on these measures, Israeli Jews were much more supportive of liberal values and much less of fundamentalism than Egyptians, Iraqis, Jordanian, Lebanese, Pakistanis, Saudis (KSA), Tunisians, or Turkish, countries for which comparative survey data were available, as shown by the figure on this page. On the other hand, the Haredi Jews are among the least liberal and most fundamentalist across the region.
